channel.title: tir
channel.description: "Today I Read:" a collection of the little things you read each day. Cherish them!

item.title: Capitalist Realism, Chapter 2
item.description: "There is a sense in which it simply is the case that the political elite are our servants; the miserable service they provide from us is to launder our libidos, to obligingly re-present for us our disavowed desires as if they had nothing to do with us."

item.title: How Wagner Shaped Hollywood
item.description: Wagner in both hegemonic and critical guises.

item.title: How to Make Biomass Energy Sustainable Again
What Color is Your Function?
item.description: Discussion of asymc patterns in multiple languages (e.g. JS, Go).

item.title: Applying "Make Invalid States Unrepresentable"
item.description: A data model can too directly reflect the terms in which you think about a problem, which can leave unnecessary room for the data to become invalid.

item.title: My Principles for Building Software
item.description: "Make Invalid States Unrepresentable" and more; good notes on system complexity.

item.title: Anti-monopoly vs. Antitrust
item.description: Argues antitrust statute is designed for corporations controlling distribution, and that content aggregation is very different.

item.title: Mutant Punk: Interview with Tetsunori Tawaraya
item.description: Tidbits on the origins of his style.

item.title: A Brief History of Data Syndication and Podcasting
item.description: Some good notes on the early commercial vision for RSS, including Apple's 3D site-exploration environment HotSauce.

item.title: Parametricism and the Autopoiesis of Architecture
item.description: Ross's point that parametricism is (just) a newly plastic modernism is strong. There's a good philosophical debate about the function of innovation in architecture. Published in Log 21.
